document: Chapter 3: User Authentication - Computer Security: Principles and Practice, 4th Edition

questions.question: User authentication is defined by NIST SP 800-63-3 as the process of establishing confidence in user identities presented electronically.
FIPS 199 defines four levels of potential impact for authentication errors: Low, Moderate, High, and Critical.
A low potential impact means an authentication error could have a severe adverse effect.
Password-based authentication is the least common form of user authentication.
A user ID determines whether a user is authorized to access the system and what privileges they have.
Passwords are stored in plaintext in modern secure systems.
Password cracking has become less effective over time due to improved security policies.
Memory cards can process data internally like a small computer.
A magnetic stripe card is an example of a memory card.
Smart tokens require a password or PIN to provide adequate security.
Smart cards contain a microprocessor, memory, and I/O ports.
Smart cards typically use only one type of memory: RAM.
EEPROM in a smart card holds temporary data generated during application execution.
Electronic Identity Cards (eID) are used only for physical access control.
PACE stands for Password Authenticated Connection Establishment.
Biometric authentication is generally cheaper and simpler than password-based authentication.
Facial characteristics and fingerprints are examples of biometric authentication factors.
Retinal patterns are rarely used in biometric systems because they are not unique.
Remote user authentication is less complex than local authentication.
Eavesdropping is a common threat in remote user authentication.
Challenge-response protocols are used to counter replay attacks in remote authentication.
ATM security relies only on memory cards without additional authentication factors.
A proactive password checker prevents users from choosing weak passwords.
A Bloom filter can be used to check passwords against a dictionary of known weak passwords.
Moderate impact level means an authentication error could have a limited adverse effect.
Smart tokens can be categorized as static, dynamic password generator, or challenge-response.
ROM in a smart card stores data that changes frequently.
Biometric systems are based on pattern recognition.
Hand geometry is not a viable biometric characteristic for authentication.
Password file access control is unnecessary if passwords are hashed.
Electronic identity cards can store digital certificates and personal data.
User dissatisfaction is a common drawback of memory card systems.
Smart cards must always be inserted into a reader to function (contactless versions do not exist).
Remote authentication threats include capturing and replaying authentication sequences.
Password selection strategies only involve encouraging users to choose longer passwords.
A high assurance level corresponds to a low potential impact in NIST guidelines.
Dynamic biometric protocols are used for remote authentication with changing biometric data.
ATM security problems often stem from weak token-based authentication alone.
A model for digital user authentication includes means of authentication and risk assessment.
Hashed passwords are immune to all forms of password cracking.
